rules: Rule1: Whenever the research team published the clinical trial, the journal peer-reviewed the study.
Rule2: Under the condition that the ethics board investigated misconduct, the journal retracted the paper.
Rule3: In the event the IRB certified the protocol, then if the protocol is valid, manufacturing drug X by the company leads to drug X being available on the market.
Rule4: Provided the NIH funded the research, the research team completed the phase 3 trial.
Rule5: Either the NIH funded the research, or the pharma company funded the research.
Rule6: Under the condition that the pharma company funded the research, then manufacturing drug X by the company results in drug X being available on the market.
Rule7: If it is not the case that team compliance with regulations leads to IRB certification of the protocol, then the FDA penalized the company.
Rule8: Should it not hold that team compliance with regulations implies IRB certification of the protocol, then the FDA did not penalize the company.
Rule9: Provided that peer review by the journal does not imply FDA approval of drug X, then the FDA rejected drug X.
Rule10: If it is not the case that completing the phase 3 trial by the research team implies drug X availability upon manufacturing, then the FDA did not suspend the trial.
Rule11: Provided that the negation of phase 3 trial completion implying drug X availability does not result in FDA trial suspension, then the ethics board investigated misconduct.
Rule12: If drug X is not available on the market, then the research team published the clinical trial.
facts: Fact2: The team is compliant with regulations.
Fact3: The company manufactured drug X.
Fact4: The journal did not retract the paper.
Fact5: The FDA did not approve drug X.
Fact6: The FDA did not reject drug X.

question: Drug X is available on the market.
